body: #64 may be related

One possible way to do this is to add a Fluo API call for loading files into a table.  This call would do the sanity check and then make the Accumulo call to bulk load files.  Could encourage users to use this API call instead of going to Accumulo directly.

With this pull request, the `CuratorFramework` objects created using the utility methods will use the Zookeeper timeout specified in `FluoConfiguration`.  Previously, no timeout parameter was given to CuratorFrameworkFactory so they were using the default timeouts for curator.  I think this is a good change.  However, let me know if you think otherwise.

I fixed one integration test initially so changes can be reviewed before being applied to all integration tests.

In the 2nd scan above, there are a lot of data entries.  Looking at the GCITer code, I am not sure what caused this.  I should have looked at the oldest time to collect in ZK.

Fixed in PR #399

I created an IT that would recreate the problem. The IT would try to modify a few rows using lots of threads.  I found the following bugs :+1: 
- `LoadTask` and `WorkTask` both retry when a collision occurs.  When the code retries it creates a new `TransactionImpl` but does not  close the one from the previous attempt.  Not closing the `TransactionImpl` when retrying prevents updating state in ZK needed for GC.
- Found that when a TX deletes a notification it uses its commit timestamp.  It should use its start timestamp.  This could cause deletion of notification that was not processed.
- Found that when a weak notification is created, it uses the start timestamp.  Should use the commit timestamp.   This could cause notification to be deleted w/o changes made being processed.

Some of the changes in the patch are best viewed ignoring white-space changes.  I removed a try block.

Keith made a good point that rather than creating a cache the oracle client could stored in the Environment object under SharedResources.  Therefore, a cache is no longer needed.

I looked into this some and ran into problems with logback vs log4j.   
- [twill email thread](http://markmail.org/message/octmf5imsmpnqbdf)
- [TWILL-122](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TWILL-122)

This looks like it was fixed when @keith-turner refactored the worker to use `NotificationProcessor` which uses `Environment` to get a Curator client.  While researching this issue, I did find several places in the code where the number curator clients in the code could be reduced.  I will create follow on issues for them.

I noticed in the three cases above that the primary column has successfully committed.   The locks were left on other columns in the transaction.  For one of those I tried scanning the two locked columns.

```
fluo scan -r 08:0iv6:08:0000000021aa4f4d
08:0iv6:08:0000000021aa4f4d count seen  1
fluo scan -r 07:s1o9:08:0000000021aa4f00
07:s1o9:08:0000000021aa4f00 count wait  1
```

Then I looked for notifications and scanning the columns had caused one to be created.

```
root@instance16 fluo> scan -c ntfy
07:s1o9:08:0000000021aa4f00 ntfy:count^Dwait [] 14101136-    
```

Eventually the node at level 6 its count corrected from 233 to 234.  First wait was set and then seen was updated.

```
[ec2-user@leader1 ~]$ fluo scan -p 06 | grep 0000000021aa0000
06:0ajr:08:0000000021aa0000 count seen  233
06:0ajr:08:0000000021aa0000 count wait  1
```

A bit of time between these.

```
[ec2-user@leader1 ~]$ fluo scan -p 06 | grep 0000000021aa0000
06:0ajr:08:0000000021aa0000 count seen  234
```

Based on this I tried scanning the entire table to clean up all locks.   

```
fluo scan > /dev/null
```

This caused a lot of notifications to be created.  Eventually the counts came out correct!

```
[ec2-user@leader1 fluo-stress]$ ./bin/print.sh 2>/dev/null
Total at root : 3992004
Nodes Scanned : 15259
```

Could use the presence of an ACK to drop delete markers during minor compaction

In the pseudo code, you recommend counting the number of outstanding notifications and sleeping a certain amount of time based off that number.  Is there particular reason for doing this?  

I am concerned it will be difficult to get the algorithm/calculation correct (and cause the wait command to sleep too long or too little).  How about just checking periodically after a a certain number of seconds (set by the user) if there are notifications still available?

>  Is there particular reason for doing this? 

Was just thinking of avoiding scanning too much

> I am concerned it will be difficult to get the algorithm/calculation correct

Should probably be 

```
  int sleepTime = f(ntfyCount, numWorkers)
```

> How about just checking periodically after a a certain number of seconds (set by the user)

I doubt the user would know what to put... I think we should make an attempt to figure something out or leave that option open for the future.   Providing a user facing config option for that kinda locks us in to that, when I think the system can do things to figure out something reasonable.
@mikewalch I think you had mentioned offline rewriting the bash script in Python.  Was there any particular reason you decided to write in Java vs Python?

I wrote it in Java because I didn't want to add a dependency on Python for a little bit of code.  While I like using Python for `fluo-deploy`, I don't think adding Python as a dependency to Fluo is worth it unless we can move a decent amount of code to Python.

I upgraded Curator to 2.7.1.  While CURATOR-21 removed the logging of this exception at one spot in the class, there are still more places where this exception can be unessarily logged.  As this issue is only seen during Fluo ITs, I submitted a PR to increase the log level for this class to FATAL for ITs.  However, this issue can be kept open until a long term solution is found.
what motivated all of the pom changes?

One reason for the pom changes was that I needed to to start up mini-accumulo in the fluo-cluster module for the new  MiniAppRunnerIT.  I also tried to use only logback in the fluo-cluster module.  However, mini-accumulo requires log4j.  Therefore, you really can't exclude one or the other.  Therefore, I removed the log4j exclusions from the pom.  These exclusion are not necessary any more as the maven assembly plugin (see bin.xml) separates log4j & logback jars into different directories.
Not sure why the ITs are failing in TravisCI as they not failing locally.
With the log level increase commit, this issue will be removed from beta milestone but will not be closed until a long-term fix is made to curator.

I removed the upgrade of Accumulo to 1.6.2 and ITs are no longer failing.  I think it's due to a bug in the iteration of our ITs & MiniAccumuloCluster.  I will create a separate follow-up issue to upgrade Accumulo and fix any failing ITs.

I looked into how this currently works and found the following.
- regular notifications are deleted when the trigger column is committed using the startTs.  In the same mutation the ACK is written.  
- regular notifications are written when an observed column is committed using the commitTs
- weak notifications are written after all locks were written but before primary column is committed.  Its dones using commitTs
- weak notifications are deleted before any locks are written (this is really really bad, notification could be completely lost w/o doing any work)

The trigger column is always chosen as the primary column.  So basically when the primary column is committed the notification is deleted.  If the worker dies after this then there will be no notification to recreate the transaction.

I am thinking that regular and weak notifications should only be deleted after the transaction is completed.  For weak notifications this may result in the transaction running multiple times, but thats ok.  For regular notifications, if a process dies after committing but before deleting the notification then the ACK should prevent it from running again.  In the case where there is an ACK, would need to delete the notification.

The project [revelc/apilyzer-maven-plugin](http://github.com/revelc/apilyzer-maven-plugin) uses the Google style, if you want to check out that POM. The one annoying part is the imports ordering is a bit broken (see checkstyle/checkstyle#941). You can satisfy the check with the right Eclipse configuration, but it's not correct according to the style guide description.

The checkstyle plugin is not configured to fail for warnings.   There are 908 checkstyle warnings that need to be fixed before this can be turned on.

```
find -type f -name checkstyle-results-java.xml | xargs grep error | wc -l
```
Warnings are now down to 159

Thinking about the implementation, could use the batch scanner and a special iterator to count notifications.  This would parallelize counting notifications.  This could be a separate issue.
Looked into this.  This is because its using MiniFluo which just scans really frequently inorder to make things responsive for users.

Workers should send out request for tablet scan asynchronously.  This approach makes it likely that when a workers scans a tablet, its doing it on behalf of many other workers.   

If a worker issued a scan request to another worker and waited, then its possible that other tablets its interested in scanning could be scanned while its waiting.
I really like how you have restructured the documentation and the readme
I think these changes look good.  I ran into some more issues trying to run phrasecount against mini from the tar ball.  I'll submit a follow on PR for those.
